title: Thomas Arthur Connolly
text:
Thomas Arthur Connolly (October 5, 1899 – April 18, 1991) was an American <a href="prelate">prelate</a> of the <a href="Catholic%20Church">Roman Catholic Church</a>. He served as the fifth <a href="bishop%20%28Catholic%20Church%29">bishop</a> and first <a href="archbishop">archbishop</a> of the <a href="Roman%20Catholic%20Archdiocese%20of%20Seattle">Archdiocese of Seattle</a> from 1950–1975. 
Born in <a href="San%20Francisco">San Francisco</a>, <a href="California">California</a>, Connolly was <a href="Holy%20Orders">ordained</a> to the <a href="Priesthood%20%28Catholic%20Church%29">priesthood</a> in San Francisco in 1926. As a priest, he held several posts in the San Francisco area before being appointed <a href="auxiliary%20bishop">auxiliary bishop</a> of the <a href="Roman%20Catholic%20Archdiocese%20of%20San%20Francisco">Archdiocese of San Francisco</a> in 1939. In 1948, Connolly was named <a href="coadjutor%20bishop">coadjutor bishop</a> of the <a href="Roman%20Catholic%20Archdiocese%20of%20Seattle">Diocese of Seattle</a> with right of succession to Bishop <a href="Gerald%20Shaughnessy">Gerald Shaughnessy</a>, who had been in poor health for several years. Archbishop Connolly, who selected the episcopal motto "Justitia et Pax" ("Justice and Peace"), took bold steps in supporting the civil rights movement, ecumenical programs, and labor issues. He attended the Second Vatican Council and helped guide the archdiocese through the tumultuous era of the 1960s.
Biography.
Thomas Connolly was born in <a href="San%20Francisco%2C%20California">San Francisco</a>, <a href="California">California</a>, to Thomas and Catherine (née Gilsenan) Connolly. After studying at <a href="Saint%20Patrick%20Seminary%2C%20Menlo%20Park">St. Patrick Seminary</a> in <a href="Menlo%20Park%2C%20California">Menlo Park</a>, he was <a href="Holy%20Orders">ordained</a> to the <a href="Priesthood%20%28Catholic%20Church%29">priesthood</a> on June 11, 1926. He then served as a <a href="curate">curate</a> at <a href="http%3A//www.stroseonline.org/">St. Rose Church</a> in <a href="Santa%20Rosa%2C%20California">Santa Rosa</a> and <a href="http%3A//www.starofthesea.us/">St. Mary Star of the Sea Church</a> in <a href="Sausalito%2C%20California">Sausalito</a>. In 1930 he was sent to further his studies at the <a href="The%20Catholic%20University%20of%20America">Catholic University of America</a> in <a href="Washington%2C%20D.C.">Washington, D.C.</a>, from where he obtained a <a href="Doctor%20of%20Canon%20Law">doctorate in canon law</a> in 1932. After his return to California, he became <a href="secretary">secretary</a> to Archbishop <a href="Edward%20Joseph%20Hanna">Edward Joseph Hanna</a> in 1934 and <a href="Chancellor%20%28ecclesiastical%29">chancellor</a> of the <a href="Roman%20Catholic%20Archdiocese%20of%20San%20Francisco">Archdiocese of San Francisco</a> in 1935. He was named a <a href="Monsignor">Domestic Prelate</a> by <a href="Pope%20Pius%20XI">Pope Pius XI</a> in 1936, and <a href="pastor">pastor</a> of <a href="Mission%20San%20Francisco%20de%20As%C3%ADs">Mission San Francisco de Asís</a> in 1939.
On June 10, 1939, Connolly was appointed <a href="Auxiliary%20Bishop">Auxiliary Bishop</a> of San Francisco and <a href="Titular%20Bishop">Titular Bishop</a> of "Sila" by <a href="Pope%20Pius%20XII">Pope Pius XII</a>. He received his <a href="Bishop%20%28Catholic%20Church%29">episcopal</a> <a href="consecration">consecration</a> on the following August 24 from Archbishop <a href="John%20Joseph%20Mitty">John Joseph Mitty</a>, with Bishops <a href="Robert%20John%20Armstrong">Robert John Armstrong</a> and <a href="Thomas%20Kiely%20Gorman">Thomas Kiely Gorman</a> serving as <a href="Consecrator">co-consecrators</a>. In 1941 he was named vicar delegate to the Catholic <a href="chaplain">chaplain</a>s serving the <a href="United%20States%20Army">Army</a> and <a href="United%20States%20Navy">Navy</a> in the <a href="Pacific%20Ocean%20theater%20of%20World%20War%20II">Pacific Coast</a>.
Connolly was named <a href="Coadjutor%20Bishop">Coadjutor Bishop</a> of <a href="Roman%20Catholic%20Archdiocese%20of%20Seattle">Seattle</a>, <a href="Washington%20%28U.S.%20state%29">Washington</a>, on February 28, 1948, with immediate right of succession to Bishop <a href="Gerald%20Shaughnessy">Gerald Shaughnessy</a>, who had been in failing health for several years. Upon Shaughnessy's death on May 18, 1950, Connolly became the fifth Bishop of Seattle. When the diocese was elevated to the rank of an <a href="Diocese">archdiocese</a> on June 23, 1951, Connolly became its first <a href="Archbishop">Archbishop</a>.
During his tenure, he became known as a "brick and mortar bishop" for his construction of hundreds of Catholic facilities to accommodate the <a href="Aftermath%20of%20World%20War%20II">post</a>-<a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a> <a href="Post-World%20War%20II%20baby%20boom">population growth</a> in the Archdiocese. He renovated <a href="St.%20James%20Cathedral%20in%20Seattle">St. James Cathedral</a>; established 43 new parishes; and built over 350 churches, schools, rectories, convents, parish halls and religious education centers. He became an <a href="Assistant%20at%20the%20Pontifical%20Throne">Assistant at the Pontifical Throne</a> in 1959. He attended all four sessions of the <a href="Second%20Vatican%20Council">Second Vatican Council</a> between 1962 and 1965. He was also an outspoken supporter of the <a href="civil%20rights%20movement">civil rights movement</a>, <a href="ecumenism">ecumenism</a>, and <a href="pro-life">pro-life</a> issues.
Connolly retired as archbishop on February 13, 1975, and died on April 18, 1991. He is interred with past bishops of Seattle at Holyrood Catholic Cemetery in <a href="Shoreline%2C%20Washington">Shoreline, Washington</a>.
